title: GitHub - chainsawriot/rang: Reconstructing R computational environments

last_post.content:
Excited to introduce the #Rstats package rang (developed by @chainsawriot and me). The pkg helps to reconstruct historical R environments to make old code run again (ie make it reproducible!). So far, it supports all code back to R 2.1.0 (2005!)
https://github.com/chainsawriot/rang


The package is an Rchaeological tool to ensure reproducibility retrospectively. You can also use rang to make your current projects future proof, but pkgs like renv or groundhog are better suited for this task.

i boosted this site earlier but i think it deserves more explanation. this is a search engine for images that shows you the copyright status for the image right there front and center and you can filter for them. for instance i grabbed this copyright 0 image of an echidna from there. and it even generated a citation for me: "Echidna on the move" by CazzJj is marked with CC0 1.0. i think this is a really easy way for getting a reference image while ensuring the person who took the image consents to its use! https://openverse.org/

Here's the chart that really matters.

Average Mastodon posts per month are going up.

Here's a comparison:

* Sept 2022: ~460M posts
* Dec 2022: ~573M posts
* Feb 2023 (so far): ~678M posts

This is a dramatic upswing in posts, and indicates that activity on Mastodon is continuing to increase.

The chart tells the story. The jump is dramatic.

Academic jobs are typically unstable and highly competitive (pre-tenure).

How does this affect science quality?

"[H]igh turnover in academic institutions fosters cursory research and hinders thorough, long-term projects. Research projects often hit a dead end when researchers drop out because their contracts have expired. Methodological expertise, which often takes years to acquire, is lost when highly skilled researchers leave."

via https://doi.org/10.1038/s41562-022-01508-2

Google’s chatbot panic

Cory Doctorow @pluralistic:

"The really remarkable thing isn’t just that Microsoft has decided that the future of search isn’t links to relevant materials, but instead lengthy, florid paragraphs written by a chatbot who happens to be a habitual liar – even more remarkable is that Google agrees."

Also:

"Every successful Google product except search and gmail is an acquisition: mobile, ad-tech, videos, server management, ... https://mitchw.blog/2023/02/16/googles-chatbot-panic.html

Last week, my colleague Kevin was ready to give up Google in favor of the new AI-powered Bing. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/08/technology/microsoft-bing-openai-artificial-intelligence.html This week, he writes about a chat with Bing's AI leaving him deeply unsettled after it told him about the many terrible things its "shadow self" wanted to do and confessed its love repeatedly for him. The cycle from enchantment to terror with new technologies is really accelerating! https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/16/technology/bing-chatbot-microsoft-chatgpt.html The convo transcript is worth a read. Unlocked: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/16/technology/bing-chatbot-transcript.html?unlocked_article_code=0nO8z_Y4baZC4ubiFGf8_8tbc9u8IxBiYfkdBdfkYrrQ3FZiSNQGQthdTGZ_95lM3GhH0b5i0HRTqlCx2RfqUPROcRrsdXlaZpvk0ZSg6zOc7NeFg3YWFvaf7wNQPFgMSN2XwqqbbaVzNfbZ_76tXk8zAkkXDKXDlqZ9vvDvKTG3vgpMa2g1Wrj3diCCS1w1kmfZSNYbsDjwmCZhuGZZf94D5THnuD4cfrXbF4TyM8gL9jK-Tozndjf4oVD-lcEapMSDtClSYcJ0_UMMMC3hO_2KNOajiVU5fTZW2X8cmStqBrIOtNhFE-be4p6LY0dPLqIoJqyTDp8Ape67rCuP-xA0JyA&smid=url-share

This is a really well-done comprehensive article on long Covid in the Scientific American, I hope others will get informed on it and start masking up to protect themselves and others, because it is common and these body systems are truly being affected, and we need to do something. To start we need others to get educated: https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/long-covid-now-looks-like-a-neurological-disease-helping-doctors-to-focus-treatments/

#LongCOVID #CovidIsNotOver #MaskUp

title: Microsoft’s ChatGPT-Powered Bing Makes Search Interesting Again

last_post.content: Last week, my colleague Kevin was ready to give up Google in favor of the new AI-powered Bing. https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/08/technology/microsoft-bing-openai-artificial-intelligence.html This week, he writes about a chat with Bing's AI leaving him deeply unsettled after it told him about the many terrible things its "shadow self" wanted to do and confessed its love repeatedly for him. The cycle from enchantment to terror with new technologies is really accelerating! https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/16/technology/bing-chatbot-microsoft-chatgpt.html The convo transcript is worth a read. Unlocked: https://www.nytimes.com/2023/02/16/technology/bing-chatbot-transcript.html?unlocked_article_code=0nO8z_Y4baZC4ubiFGf8_8tbc9u8IxBiYfkdBdfkYrrQ3FZiSNQGQthdTGZ_95lM3GhH0b5i0HRTqlCx2RfqUPROcRrsdXlaZpvk0ZSg6zOc7NeFg3YWFvaf7wNQPFgMSN2XwqqbbaVzNfbZ_76tXk8zAkkXDKXDlqZ9vvDvKTG3vgpMa2g1Wrj3diCCS1w1kmfZSNYbsDjwmCZhuGZZf94D5THnuD4cfrXbF4TyM8gL9jK-Tozndjf4oVD-lcEapMSDtClSYcJ0_UMMMC3hO_2KNOajiVU5fTZW2X8cmStqBrIOtNhFE-be4p6LY0dPLqIoJqyTDp8Ape67rCuP-xA0JyA&smid=url-share

Upheaval Dome, Utah

Upheaval Dome in Utah is 3.4 mile-diameter bull’s eye-shaped feature in Canyonlands National Park so large it can be seen from space. The rock layers in the center form an eroded dome (anticline) exposing the oldest rocks in the center, surrounded by down-sloping younger rocks (syncline).

There has been much debate over the formation of Upheaval Dome. It has come down to two major hypotheses: a. It was formed by a pinched-off salt diapir - the salt deposits deep below were more buoyant and bubbled up doming and intruding the overlying rock which has since been eroded down b. It was formed by the impact of a meteorite over 457 feet across as evidenced by shocked quartz grains. The Park website still includes both hypotheses although they reference this study as the most recent findings: https://pubs.geoscienceworld.org/gsa/geology/article-abstract/36/3/227/29673/Upheaval-Dome-Utah-USA-Impact-origin-confirmed They go on to say that many questions still remain. Anyone who has the latest findings, please weigh in here.

More on the geology here: https://geology.utah.gov/map-pub/survey-notes/geosights/upheaval-dome/

A beautiful aerial view of Upheaval Dome here: https://epod.usra.edu/blog/2013/04/upheaval-dome-in-canyonlands-national-park.html

Image from: https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/7887/upheaval-dome-utah

Stable Horde has grown so meteorically, in the past few months that I am in a state of constant firefighting around infrastructure woes, and can barely onboard new features. If I didn't have a few dedicated community members doing helping, I would just be focused on keeping it afloat.

title: On the Dangers of Stochastic Parrots | Proceedings of the 2021 ACM Conference on Fairness, Accountability, and Transparency

last_post.content:
"Contrary to how it may seem when we observe its output, an LM is a system for haphazardly stitching together sequences of linguistic forms it has observed in its vast training data, according to probabilistic information about how they combine, but without any reference to meaning: a stochastic parrot."

They really did amazing work on the paper. You can read it *for free*.

It's here:

https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3442188.3445922

title: Bluetooth tracker Tile is taking a new approach to stopping thieves and stalkers

last_post.content:
Tile makes a tracker app so that you can detect unwanted Tiles following you around, and now they have announced an "anti-theft mode" that makes the Tile undetectable to the detection app. Way to miss the fucking point.

This is your regular reminder that you CANNOT make a physical tracker that tracks thieves without alerting them without also creating a perfect tool for stalkers.

https://www.cnbc.com/2023/02/16/bluetooth-tracker-tile-has-new-approach-for-stopping-thieves-stalkers.html

title: Task Force for a Trustworthy Future Web

last_post.content: I'm part of @DFRLab 's new Task Force for a Trustworthy #FutureWeb (and I'm in dauntingly impressive company). I'm excited to help generate a report to guide future tech policy on some topics that are important to me, such as encryption and online trust & safety: https://www.atlanticcouncil.org/programs/digital-forensic-research-lab/democracy-and-tech-initiative/future-web/

Just pushed another #pdiiif update to https://pdiiif.jbaiter.de :
Previously the PDFs would fail to render in some viewers (Acrobat, Edge). This should be fixed now.
Let me know if it still breaks for you!

[
gory details: messed up the PDF/ZIP polyglot implementation ever so slightly, breaking some hardcoded out-of-spec expectations in those viewers. Taking a closer look at how PoC||GTFO implemented it (thanks @Ange , again) led to the fix.
https://github.com/jbaiter/pdiiif/commit/28bf91645e750f95a9691e8f44a6f6f0b3082a61
]

title: Case Study — Machine learning about sexual orientation?

last_post.content:
Michal Kosinksi just posted an arXiv paper claiming that "Theory of mind may have spontaneously emerged" in GPT3.

arxiv.org/abs/2302.02083

Why? He administered theory of mind instruments to the bot and it performed well.

Dr. Kosinksi has struggled before with how inference works; he thought the performance of his AI gaydar detector provided evidence for the prenatal hormone exposure hypothesis for sexual orientation rather than, say, self-presentation choices.

https://www.callingbullshit.org/case_studies/case_study_ml_sexual_orientation.html

title: The Slackers - Live at Sanctuary Detroit, MI 11/13/2022 - 1 of 3

last_post.content:
Hey, it's been a bit since I did a #music post, so rather than doing a single song, I'm going to post 25 minutes of a recent live set by the Slackers (a band I've seen more than any other band ever, by a wide margin).

They have tons of live videos, but the recording on this one is good, the set list is good (kicking off with a cover of work song, which lets them do some cool solos), and there's some fun Vic banter between songs if you watch the whole thing.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXFBi46sjRY

title: "That's where I draw the line": David Cross has words for comics who moan about cancel culture

last_post.content:
"All the comics who b***h and moan about [cancel culture]... For what? Your dumb joke about trans people? Who gives a s**t? I mean, is it that important to you? Just move on and not hurt hundreds of thousands of people. It's a choice people make..."

"That's where I draw the line": David Cross has words for comics who moan about cancel culture | Salon.com
https://www.salon.com/2023/02/16/david-cross-worst-daddy-comedy-tour-salon-talks/

In the huge Safari/Webkit update today we missed the significant improvements in Web Components: Declarative Shadow DOM, ElementInternals, form-associated custom elements, Imperative Slot API.

Another important building block of Web Apps.

https://developer.apple.com/documentation/safari-release-notes/safari-16_4-release-notes

It is very important for all of us to recognize the hard work of the dedicated engineers working to bring this functionality to Safari, and to draw a distinction between their work and corporate decisions outside of their control.

Head’s up. The crypto world is trying really hard to pivot towards decentralized social media.

It’s important for everyone to know that the Fediverse has NOTHING to do with cryptocurrency, or NFTs, or whatever Ponzi scheme the “coin” hucksters have been trying to peddle.

Whenever something gets trendy, that’s when the bottom feeders arrive.

https://www.blockworks.co/news/web3-social-media-apps-to-watch

title: How should AI systems behave, and who should decide?

last_post.content:
Today, OpenAI posted, "How should AI systems behave, and who should decide?"¹ (6 minute read). Inside they link to a document that's "a portion of our guidelines that pertain to political and controversial topics".² It states, "the Assistant should provide a refusal" to requests for inappropriate content, including "content attempting to influence the political process or to be used for campaigning purposes."

#aiEthics #PoliticalTech

¹ https://openai.com/blog/how-should-ai-systems-behave/
² https://cdn.openai.com/snapshot-of-chatgpt-model-behavior-guidelines.pdf

title: Ron DeSantis' hypocrisy is his secret weapon

last_post.content:
"In essence what Gov. DeSantis and conservative groups like Moms for Liberty are saying is this: The problem is not that white America has been abusing Black America throughout our history and into the present, but that Black Americans keep remembering this history and telling it to white people—which somehow victimizes white people. My verb choice here is deliberate: This is the psychology of the abuser."

https://www.salon.com/2023/02/15/ron-desantis-hypocrisy-is-his-secret-weapon/

To the EU, any company with more than 45 million users is a "very large online platform".

As a result, Google, Meta, and Twitter face stiffer EU online content rules.

These rules favour de-centralized Fediverse services like Mastodon, @pixelfed, and @peertube—and incentivize a need for no one instance to dominate.

The EU operates an official Mastodon instance (social.network.europa.eu) so it's clear that the Fediverse is a consideration.

https://ca.finance.yahoo.com/news/google-twitter-meta-face-tougher-000819087.html

@fediversenews

---
RT @willsommer
This filing in the Dominion lawsuit against Fox News is one of the most remarkable documents I've ever seen. Filled with private texts between Fox stars like Hannity and Carlson, plus Murdoch, all admitting they knew Fox's stolen election claims were lies. https://int.nyt.com/data/documenttools/redacted-documents-in-dominion-fox-news-case/dca5e3880422426f/full.pdf
https://twitter.com/willsommer/status/1626382493480878080

The US is so dystopian that I genuinely need to clarify that:

* Housed people commit *significantly* more crime against homeless people than vice versa. Housed people also commit more crime against other housed people.

* The solution for "people with untreated mental illness living in the subway" is neither "involuntary detention in a mental institution" nor "forced medication." It is "Affordable and accessible mental healthcare, medication, and housing."

title: Microsoft says talking to Bing for too long can cause it to go off the rails

last_post.content:
"Microsoft says talking to Bing for too long can cause it to go off the rails" https://www.theverge.com/2023/2/16/23602335/microsoft-bing-ai-testing-learnings-response

We've seen the giant Bing leaked prompt... surely they haven't engineered Bing in such a way that the prompt that sets it up can scroll out of the token context window and be forgotten?

GPT-3's token window is 4,097 tokens, but I wouldn't be at all surprise if the Bing model is a bit bigger than that

But yeah, surely that's not how it works?

Just a quick reminder, when you put your code on GitHub (or any other public code repository), please add a proper licence so that it can be reused. For formal packages, MIT, GPL-* or other similar licences are common. For text content a Creative Commons licence is useful.

Here are a few resources to get you started.

https://r-pkgs.org/license.html (also works with Python and Julia or other languages)
https://creativecommons.org/

#RStats #JuliaLang #Python #ReproducibleResearch
